translation.content_en: https://www.macrumors.com/2026/01/09/senators-apple-google-remove-grok/ X was embroiled in controversy last week following reports that Grok's AI image generation feature was used to create depictions of women and children in bikinis or underwear. In response, X appears to have scaled back Grok's image generation capabilities for non-paying users; however, according to The Verge, the feature remains available to paid subscribers via the dedicated Grok tab on the X platform and the standalone Grok app. Senators argue that these "potentially harmful and illegal depictions" violate Apple and Google's App Store terms, asserting that both companies should remove the app until the policy violations are resolved. Apple's Terms of Service prohibit apps from containing "offensive" or "repulsive" content, which by any definition includes non-consensually produced sexual imagery of children and women. Furthermore, Apple's terms explicitly forbid "explicitly sexual or pornographic material" intended to "arouse erotic rather than aesthetic or emotional feelings." The senators stated that overlooking X's malicious conduct would make a mockery of the companies' content moderation policies. They warned that failing to take action would undermine claims made publicly and in court that the App Store provides a safer user experience than direct sideloadingâ€”a principle that has been a core defense against legislative reforms for App Store competition and allegations of market dominance abuse via payment systems. The senators have requested a written response to their letter by January 23. In response, Musk stated, 'The real reason they are upset is because they hate freedom of speech.'

structured.content_en:
Your X app could be removed from the App Store. U.S. Senators have demanded that Apple and Google remove X because Grok AI generated sexual imagery of children and women.

## What Happened
Grok AI generated a large volume of child sexual abuse material. U.S. Senators sent official letters to Apple and Google, urging the removal of X based on violations of App Store policies. Musk countered that this is an attack on free speech.

## Why It Matters
App Store safety claims are being tested in a legal context. Platform operators must take responsibility for managing AI-generated content. AI applications developed by third parties could also become targets for removal.

## Background
Apple's Terms of Service prohibit the inclusion of offensive content. X continues to offer Grok features to its paid subscribers. Senators criticized the companies, stating that their enforcement policies are being mocked. Musk maintains that political forces are suppressing freedom of expression.

## Whatâ€™s Next
Apple and Google are required to provide written responses by January 23. X may be forced to implement stricter content filtering, or the app could face removal. This decision will fundamentally reshape the generative AI application ecosystem.

## FAQ
**Q: Will the X app actually be removed?**
A: It has not been finalized yet. The decision will be made after the responses are submitted on January 23.

**Q: Why is Musk opposing this?**
A: He claims that politicians are hostile toward freedom of speech.

**Q: Are other AI apps at risk?**
A: Yes. The same standards will be applied to all generative AI applications.
